title: Sparganosis
parasite_biology:
### Causal Agents

Cestodes in the genus _Spirometra_ , including _S. mansoni, S. ranarum, S.
mansonoides and S. erinacei_ , as well as the aberrant _Sparganum proliferum_.

### Life Cycle

![lifecycle](/dpdx/sparganosis/modules/Sparganosis_LifeCycle.gif?_=00551)

Adult members of the genus _Spirometra_ live in the intestines of dogs and
cats ![The number
7](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_7.gif).
Eggs are shed in feces ![The number
1](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/large_intestine_1.gif)
and embryonate in the environment ![The number
2](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_2.gif). Eggs
hatch in water and release coracidia ![The number
3](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_3.gif), which
are ingested by copepods. The coracidia develop into procercoid larvae in the
copepod intermediate host ![The number
4](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4.gif). Second
intermediate hosts, including fish, reptiles and amphibians, ingest infected
copepods and acquire procercoid larvae. The procercoid larvae develop into
plerocercoid larvae in the second intermediate host ![The number
5](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_5.gif). The
cycle is completed when a predator (dog or cat) eats an infected second
intermediate host ![The number
6](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_6.gif). Humans
cannot serve as definitive hosts for _Spirometra_ spp., but serve as paratenic
or second intermediate hosts ![The number
8.](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/stomach_8.gif) and
develop sparganosis. Humans acquire sparganosis by either drinking water
contaminated with infected copepods or consuming the flesh of an under-cooked
second intermediate or paratenic host. Spargana can live up to 20 years in the
human host.

### Geographic Distribution

The genus _Spirometra_ occurs worldwide in distribution, although most human
cases of sparganosis are recorded from southeast Asian countries. Sparganosis
is endemic in animals throughout North America, although human cases from this
area are rare.

### Clinical Presentation

Migrating spargana cause various symptoms depending on the final location in
the host. Spargana may locate anywhere, including subcutaneous tissue, breast,
orbit, urinary tract, pleural cavity, lungs, abdominal viscera and the central
nervous system. The migration in subcutaneous tissues is usually painless, but
when spargana settle in the brain or spine a variety of neurological symptoms
may occur, including weakness, headache, seizure, and abnormal skin
sensations, such as numbness or tingling. If the inner ear is involved, the
patient may experience vertigo or deafness. Occasionally, _Sparganum
proliferum_ can cause proliferative lesions in the infected tissue, with
multiple plerocercoids present in a single site.
image_gallery:
##### Proliferating spargana in groin tissue.

Sparganosis is infection by the third-stage plerocercoid larva (sparganum) of
pseudophyllidean cestodes of the genera _Spirometra_ and _Sparganum_ , the
latter of which may be an aberrant _Spirometra_ sp. The definitive hosts for
_Spirometra_ spp. are _canids_ and _felids_ , and humans serve as only
paratenic or second intermediate hosts for the parasites. Spargana can be
found in many organs in the human host, including the pleural cavity, eyes,
pericardium, abdominal cavity and viscera, and the central nervous system.

![](/dpdx/sparganosis/images/1/Sparganosis_groin_Paraguay_BAM1.jpg?_=00561)

Figure A: Proliferating sparganum in groin tissue of a patient from Paraguay,
stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

lab_diagnosis:
### Laboratory Diagnosis

Diagnosis is usually made by the recovery of a sparganum from infected tissue.
The presence of a sparganum is diagnostic and identification to the species
level is usually not warranted. However, the best way to identify the species
is to infect an appropriate definitive host with a living sparganum and
identify the adult after maturation.
